answers.feedback_html: Kepler’s laws are descriptive and do not contain any causal information. Newton’s law shows the cause.
Kepler’s laws are not causal in nature. They don’t give information about the cause of planetary motion.

answers.content_html: Kepler’s laws are descriptive as well as causal.
answers.feedback_html: It is correct that Kepler’s laws are descriptive in nature. But they do not explain the cause of planetary motion.

answers.content_html: Kepler’s laws are neither descriptive nor causal.
answers.feedback_html: It is correct that Kepler’s laws do not explain the cause of planetary motion. But they do provide a description of planetary motion.

stem_html: Are Kepler’s laws purely descriptive, or do they contain causal information?

answers.feedback_html: The length of the semi-major axis is not the product of the focal distance and eccentricity. It can be calculated by division of the focal distance by the eccentricity.
The length of the semi-major axis of an ellipse is given by the formula \frac{f}{e} and not \frac{f}{2e}.
If you divide focal distance by eccentricity, it gives the length of the semi-major axis of an ellipse.
The length of the semi-major axis of an ellipse is given by the formula f/e and not 2f/e.

stem_html: The focal point of the elliptical orbit of a moon is 50,000\,\text{km} from the center of the orbit. If the eccentricity of the orbit is 0.25, what is the length of the semi-major axis?

answers.content_html: The mass of the parent body must be much less than that of the satellite.
answers.feedback_html: Consider the fact that the satellite revolves around the parent body, which means the parent body must be stationary to apply Kepler’s laws.

answers.content_html: The mass of the parent body must be much greater than that of the satellite.
answers.feedback_html: To apply Kepler’s laws of planetary motion, the mass of the parent body must be much larger than that of the satellite.

answers.content_html: The mass of the parent body must be equal to the mass of the satellite.
answers.feedback_html: It is not necessary for the masses to be equal to apply Kepler’s law.

answers.content_html: There is no specific relationship between the masses for applying Kepler’s laws of planetary motion.
answers.feedback_html: Recall that there is a specific relationship between the mass of the parent body and the satellite in Kepler’s laws of planetary motion. Consider the fact that the satellite revolves around the parent body.

stem_html: Explain how the masses of a satellite and its parent body must compare in order to apply Kepler’s laws of planetary motion.

answers.content_html: An ellipse is an open curve wherein the sum of the distance from the foci to any point on the curve is constant.
answers.feedback_html: Review the definition of an ellipse. It is not an open curve.

answers.content_html: An ellipse is a closed curve wherein the sum of the distance from the foci to any point on the curve is constant.
answers.feedback_html: This is the correct definition of an ellipse.

answers.content_html: An ellipse is an open curve wherein the distances from the two foci to any point on the curve are equal.
answers.feedback_html: An ellipse is not an open curve. Also, in an ellipse distances from the two foci to any point on the curve are not always equal.

answers.content_html: An ellipse is a closed curve wherein the distances from the two foci to any point on the curve are equal.
answers.feedback_html: It is correct that an ellipse is a closed curve. But you need to review the second part of the definition of an ellipse.

stem_html: The orbits of satellites are elliptical. Define an ellipse.
